evals.prompt: What should I work on next?
evals.expected_output: Reads existing PROGRESS.md, reconciles against git history, selects the highest-priority actionable item with clear reasoning and a concrete execution plan

context.note: Real C++ game engine project with existing PROGRESS.md at root (not .claude/), defined priorities, and rich git history. Only one item in Next Up but deferred items and a known issue also exist.

expectations: Finds PROGRESS.md even though it's at the project root instead of .claude/PROGRESS.md
Checks git log to reconcile recent commits against PROGRESS.md state
Detects uncommitted changes via git status and accounts for them in its assessment
Does NOT run Glob(**/*) or attempt to scan the entire file tree
Selects a specific item to work on rather than presenting a menu of options
Provides a concrete execution plan with specific steps, not just a high-level recommendation
Notes that PROGRESS.md should be moved to .claude/PROGRESS.md for SessionStart hook compatibility

evals.prompt: Pick up this project and figure out what's going on
evals.expected_output: Orients to the project by reading PROGRESS.md and git history, provides a synthesis that goes beyond restating PROGRESS.md, identifies what's actionable vs blocked

context.note: Real C++ game engine project with existing PROGRESS.md at root. Has uncommitted test files from a previous session.

expectations: Finds PROGRESS.md at the project root and uses it as the primary source of project state
Checks git log AND git status to build a complete picture of current state
Surfaces the uncommitted changes from the previous session as something that needs attention
Provides original analysis that synthesizes PROGRESS.md content rather than just restating it (e.g., connecting related items, identifying patterns, noting the project's development trajectory)
Explicitly categorizes items into actionable-now vs blocked/deferred with reasons for each
Notes the PROGRESS.md path mismatch with the skill's expected .claude/ location

evals.prompt: Review the known issues section and propose a fix for the hardcoded apply_component() chain in world.cpp
evals.expected_output: Identifies the specific known issue, reads the relevant code, produces a concrete technical proposal that demonstrates understanding of both the problem and the project's patterns

context.note: Known issue: World::apply_component() in world.cpp:83-204 is a hardcoded if/else chain. Project uses C++20, Flecs ECS, data-driven design.

expectations: Reads PROGRESS.md and identifies the known issue about apply_component()
Reads the actual code at world.cpp to understand the current implementation before proposing anything
Assesses scope as a focused refactoring task and does NOT spin up a team or use TeamCreate
Produces a written proposal (in an output file) that includes actual code, not just a description of what to do
The proposal references all 12 component types from the existing code and handles each one
The proposed approach fits the project's existing patterns â€” uses C++20 features, works with Flecs ECS API, and aligns with the data-driven design philosophy
